item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description:
Have you tried enabling the auto_detect_line_endings setting in your php.ini? If this is a Macintosh related line-ending issue this may help. WordPress is using the PHP "file()" function to read in the stylesheet, so PHP is the one having difficulty with the line-ending.

edited on: 03-07-05 22:44

item.description:
I've done a little more testing. I have tried this on today's nightly and the 3/5 one. I have used my theme and the default theme. Both themes will return the error I was talking about. However, if I had the hidden fields as mentioned before it will work.

I have also tried deleting my email and readding it, in hopes that WP will reestablish something in the database it was looking for. This did not prove sucesssful. I'm kind of stuck now. Not sure what I should test. I'm going to try and completely delete my WP files (except the database) and reinstall. Has this been reproduced by anyone?

item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) updated
item.dc:creator: cavemonkey50
item.description:
Well, first of all no hacks are used. Second, require email setting is on, but the users have a correct email set.

I have attached two files. In comments1.php, the template code I was attempting to use is used. In comments2.php I have modified the <?php if ( $user_ID ) : ?> section to include hidden fields of the name, email, and url. Line 82 in both files is the starting point of the relating comment code.

comments2.php is currently working for me, however I'm not sure if that's how the comments.php was intended to be used. In all of the themes I was looking at there were no hidden fields in the <?php if ( $user_ID ) : ?> section of the template. I probably should mention that the template I'm using is my own custom template, but I have insure I am not missing any tags.

Again, to repeat this problem, when using comments1.php, a logged in user's comment will fail and a guest who's name, email, and url fields showing will not. comments2.php will work correctly. If you need any additional information, just let me know.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
Never mind.

Now that I found the fix, it seems that post 0000902 is the same problem and claims to be resolved. Sorry to waste your time.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description: BTW -- I am told on #WordPress that I should let you know that this applies to 1.5 stayhorn.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
I have uploaded the diff output of a patch that fixes the problem.

menu-header was being called, which used the $page_hook variable in the global space for generating the menu, which overwrote what was in there previously and is why the last item (in alpha order) was the one being called every time.

item.title: Ticket #948 (Authors without e-mail specified cannot comment) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I had a patch for this a while ago but forgot to upload it or fix upstream... (michel v)

edited on: 03-07-05 10:46

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
If you add:

echo $page_hook;

before and after the following code block around line 48ish:

if ( $page_hook ) {

if (! isset($_GETnoheader?))

require_once(ABSPATH . '/wp-admin/admin-header.php');

You get different values. Prior to including the header, the value is what it should be and after loading the header, the value becomes what it would be for the last added plugin.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) created
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
Basicly, it comes down to do_action() in relation to this stack:

add_options_page() -> add_submenu_page() -> add_action()

I am still trying to determine why this happens, however I am fairly confident that it is a WordPress bug

item.title: Ticket #1045 (Feed rewrite rules being written out for pages) updated
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1045 (Feed rewrite rules being written out for pages) created
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description:
In classes.php, the function to generate the rewrite rules for the new static pages doesn't set the feed flag to false, and feed rewrite rules are being written. It's not that big a deal, except that the .htaccess file can grow by leaps and bounds.

I assume that a static page doesn't really need a feed, and have changed the code to set this flag to false.

item.title: Ticket #1044 (Parameter accidentally overwritten in code) updated
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1044 (Parameter accidentally overwritten in code) created
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description:
In the classes.php file, the generate_rewrite_rules function has a parameter called $feed. Unfortunately, the first functionality in the file accidentally overwrites this, so when it's tested later in the code, the value is no longer viable.

I've patched the code in my copy of the file to the following (first few lines)--:

function generate_rewrite_rules($permalink_structure, $pageflg = true, $feedflg = true, $forcomments = false, $walk_dirs = true) {

$feedregex2 = ; foreach ($this->feeds as $feed) {

$feedregex2 .= $feed . '|';

}

And then use $feedflg later to test to see whether feed entries should be generated.

item.title: Ticket #1042 (get_links() doesn't respect before, between and after link text) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #1042 (get_links() doesn't respect before, between and after link text) updated
item.dc:creator: Kings
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1042 (get_links() doesn't respect before, between and after link text) created
item.dc:creator: Kings
item.description:
The get_links() function has the before, between and after link text hard-coded in, despite the fact that you can change it in the Links Manager.

The fix is really easy, and I've already fixed it on my own WP install. I'm a bit suprised this isn't fixed yet but I did check the trunk, and it's still hard-coded in.

I've attached a file with the instructions to fix it.

item.title: Ticket #1041 (Pingback texts (Suggestion)) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1041 (Pingback texts (Suggestion)) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
WP currently chops pingback texts in a somewhat ugly manner.

It would be nice if, rather than taking a more or less random part of the text around the link, WP would take the sentence in which the link appears. And maybe perhaps the sentence immediately before and after in the paragraph (if any), to better put the link in context.

-- denis _\@/_ semiologic.com

item.title: Ticket #1012 (Rss2 feed) updated
item.dc:creator: kdotcom
item.description:
Still no solution from feedburner working for me.

I have tried: changing (false === strpos($_SERVERPATH_INFO?, 'index.php')) to (false === strpos($_SERVERPATH_INFO?, '.php'))

I have tried commenting out: /* if ( preg_match('/cgi/', php_sapi_name()) )

@header('Status: 404 Not Found');

else

@header('HTTP/1.x 404 Not Found'); */

Nothing is working. The RSS feed is legit, confirmed everywhere, but feedburner is not getting it to work because of something. Thoughts?

item.title: Ticket #1012 (Rss2 feed) updated

item.description:

item.title: Ticket #1023 (get_links() ignores $echo setting) updated
item.dc:creator: tivac
item.description:
I took a look at it and programmed in a simple fix that buffers the output to a variable called $output. At the end of the script it does an if() check against the value of $echo. If true $output is echoed, false causes it to be returned.

EDIT: I totally spaced and that first patch has two echo statements that were not replaced. I'm uploading a new patch and lashing myself severely for not being more careful about checking.

edited on: 03-06-05 09:30

item.title: Ticket #1038 (Limit access to php files) created

item.description:

Access can be limited with the <Files> and <FilesMatch> directives.

item.title: Ticket #1037 (Add SSL support for admin operations) created

item.description: It would be nice to have client and admin stuff separated, so that all stuff that needs passwords/cookies can be routed over SSL while all client stuff (reading, posting comments) still can go entirely over unencrypted connections.
